newsitem.title: CANADA: BASEBALL-PIAZZA HOMERS TWICE AS DODGERS EDGE EXPOS IN 10.
newsitem.headline: BASEBALL-PIAZZA HOMERS TWICE AS DODGERS EDGE EXPOS IN 10.

text.p: Mike Piazza's second homer of the game, a solo shot leading off the 10th inning, gave the Los Angeles Dodgers a 5-4 win over the Montreal Expos Tuesday.

Piazza, who belted a three-run homer in the first, lashed an 0-2 offering from Expos closer Ugueth Urbina (3-8) over the centre-field fence for his 24th homer of the season to give the Dodgers their eighth win in 10 games.

"He is a real tough guy, a tough pitcher," Piazza said. "I fought a real tough slider, 0-2. It was a really nasty pitch. Fortunately, he challenged me in there again. I didn't try to do too much with it. I just pulled my hands in and got the barrel of the bat on it."
Piazza came into the game just 1-for-13 on the road trip before collecting three hits.

Montreal pinch-hitter Darren Fletcher hit his career-high 13th homer of the season off Todd Worrell (2-3) with one out in the bottom of the ninth, knotting the game at 4-4. Worrell got the win despite suffering his seventh blown save of the season for the Dodgers, who led 4-0 after five innings.

"We battled back, but Piazza was a one-man wrecking crew tonight," Fletcher said. "We tried to crowd him inside, because we don't like to let him extend his hands. He was able to extend through the zone, and he crushed it like a 3-iron."

Dodgers starter Pedro Astacio allowed three runs and eight hits over 6 2/3 innings with five strikeouts and no walks. In his last four outings, the right-hander has yielded just five runs over 29 1/3 innings.
The Dodgers trail San Francisco by 1 1/2 games in the National League West.
In Pittsburgh, Jason Kendall and Jose Guillen homered in a four-run fourth inning and ex-Brave Jason Schmidt won his third straight game as the Pirates edged Atlanta 5-4.
Schmidt (7-6) allowed four runs and five hits over seven innings for his sixth win in his last eight decisions.
Rich Loiselle notched two of his three strikeouts in the ninth with a runner on third for his 18th save in 20 chances.
Tom Glavine (10-6) took the loss for Atlanta, whose lead over Florida in the N.L. East shrank to 4 1/2 games.
At Florida, Moises Alou's bases-loaded two-run single with one out in the bottom of the ninth lifted the Marlins to their third straight victory, 6-5 over the Houston Astros.
Alou fouled off three pitches from Astros closer Billy Wagner (7-4) before lining a 1-2 pitch into right, scoring Edgar Renteria and pinch-runner Kurt Abbott.
Closer Robb Nen (8-2) allowed one hit in a scoreless ninth as the Marlins won for the seventh time in eight games.
In New York, Edgardo Alfonzo's bases-loaded sacrifice fly with one out in the bottom of the 10th scored Bernard Gilkey as the Mets edged the St Louis Cardinals 5-4.

After the Mets rallied with a run in the bottom of the ninth to tie the game, the Cardinals had a pair of runners in the top of the 10th against closer John Franco. But steady rain turned into a torrential downpour and the game was halted for 95 minutes.
When play resumed, Corey Lidle (5-1) struck out Gary Gaetti to preserve the tie. Tony Fossas (1-4) took the loss.
New York's Pete Harnisch, in his first start of the season after a battle with depression, went six innings and yielded two runs on five hits with three strikeouts and a walk.

In Chicago, Bill Mueller snapped an eighth-inning tie with a three-run triple and Danny Darwin and two relievers combined on a five-hitter, leading the San Francisco Giants to their third straight victory, 8-2 over the Cubs.
Julian Tavarez (4-3) worked two scoreless innings for the victory and Roberto Hernandez pitched the ninth.
Cubs reliever Bob Patterson (1-5) took the loss.
In Cincinnati, Reggie Sanders had three hits including a three-run homer as the Reds defeated the reeling San Diego Padres 7-3.

Fill-in starter Mike Remlinger (4-4) struck out a career-high nine batters over five innings. Remlinger came out of the bullpen to make his second start of the season and allowed three runs, seven hits and three walks.
Scott Sullivan added three scoreless innings, striking out four, before Jeff Shaw finished up with a scoreless ninth. Cincinnati pitchers recorded 14 strikeouts.
Tony Gwynn went 2-for-4, raising his average to .390 for the Padres, who have lost six of their last seven games.
In Philadelphia, Eric Young's run-scoring double with two outs in the eighth capped a three-run rally and lifted the Colorado Rockies past the Phillies, 4-2.
The Rockies rallied from a 2-0 deficit against closer Ricky Bottalico (2-4). Darren Holmes (4-2) notched the victory with two scoreless innings in relief.
